author: {'steamid': '76561198043519546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1708881560}
review:
[h1]Doubtlessly a masterpiece. Overflowing with love, dedicated to its originality. Exceeds anything I could say in mere words.[/h1]
[h2]The short of it:[/h2]
SeaBed is unique in many waysâ€“atmosphere, story, themes, how it handles conventions and answering its questionsâ€“and is somehow familiar, not just in unlocking secret memories, but also in its high quality and presentation, like a golden age kinetic novel that time traveled years into the future. It is a doujin circle's novella with humble origins, but I think it surpasses such classics in a very pure way.
This is a very, very intimate story. The seeds of SeaBed's nonlinear mystery are deftly planted in its travel literature-esque first few chapters. The prose must be commended for its gorgeous and staggering level of detail, invoking a sensation I could only describe as meditative astral travel, or reading a painting. With a slow, almost obsessive progression early on, I understand that SeaBed may initially seem inaccessible if you aren't interested in slow burn romantic recollection, or the taste of foreign cuisine, but I promise, I [b]promise[/b], it develops and pays off incredibly well. I was quickly enraptured by the subtle and mature romantic storytelling, as well as its interspersed intrigue-building oddities. The love the characters have for each other feels incredibly genuine, and the strange events that occur are blindsiding. Scenes often feel extremely compartmentalized, making progression itself feel episodic, almost confusing, but aberrations become much more strange and significant this way. Thereâ€™s also an accompanying unique emotional synchronization between the characters and the reader, on top of the empathy created through rich storytelling, emotional connection feels diegetic. These aspects of the episodic writing kept me coming back. I recommend following suit with the story's structure and tuning in repeatedly rather than binge readingâ€“the chapters themselves are separated into discrete parts, encouraging not to use chapters as bookmarks. As the story progresses, SeaBedâ€™s slices of life begin to harmonize with an increased presence of its aberrations to create something truly unique, not a roller coaster of highs and lows, but a warm and gentle blend of flavors that rewards a discerning palate. Scene minutiae frequently serve multiple simultaneous purposes, which I will confidently call excellent writing. Nothing comes at the cost of something else, as the ethereal atmosphere and intrigue build, relationships gain more depth and become more nuanced. There is no loss of focus on detail. Romance is not sidelined, love deepens. Drama becomes more dramatic, even the comedy more comedicâ€“SeaBed is refreshingly happy too. There's a format shift, from a pick up, put down, pick up again anthology to a gripping, more cohesive narrative that demands more and more attention as threads intertwine, with an unbelievable ending. And of course, thereâ€™s no shortage of very cute scenarios. Gets my highest possible praise. Worth full price. Saved my life. Will certainly be rereading again and again; SeaBed rewards it.
[h2]Extra thoughts on the medium:[/h2]
SeaBed capitalizes on its immersive elements. Music is appropriate, SFX are atmospheric. At times, music may prime emotions early, but there are sufficient surprises in track choice and progression to avoid problems. Sound is once in a while jarring, but its presence always adds. Backgrounds are a mix of photography and 3D renders. The photographs contribute significantly to the dreamlike atmosphere, and the renders display a high amount of detailâ€“rooms are rendered faithfully according to text, such that very rarely, that text may even be redundant.
I love the illustrations. I think the art has a very quaint quality, contributing to a sense of "modern classic.â€ Characters each have their own share of characteristic and distinct expressions. I also felt spoiled by the large number of stills present for significant scenes. The writer also being the character artist greatly facilitates cohesion between text and illustration, making stills stand out as high points, at high points. Also the characters are all really cute. The art is cute.
Visual assets are also used creatively.
Menuing is not very fast, and widescreen retains 4:3. I donâ€™t find this hampers the quality.
[b]Credits seem to be buggy and flash.[/b]
[h2]Extra thoughts on the writing:[/h2]
The character writing is excellent. The text display spans the full screen without extra interface assets, but characters are so well distinguished from each other that it is trivial to understand who has said what in a conversation, without name tags, even if reading were interrupted, which is also a testament to the translation quality. The main characters are obviously well developed, but the secondary cast easily earns its screen time and is absolutely integral to the story. Personalities compliment each other incredibly well, especially with the main couple.
The translation is great. There are very few, very minor typosâ€“nothing that ultimately detracts. The flow deserves a lot of praise. No awkward moments or stilted dialogue whatsoever.
When I say that SeaBed "exceeds anything I could say in mere words," I mean that it transcends what terminology might imply. â€œSlice of life'' does not adequately describe the depths of humanity it explores, and "mundane" fails to capture the significance of its microscopic details. Romantic love is core to the story, but right away, SeaBed speaks its perspective on the importance of friendship too, next to and as part of romance, not just as an alternative or stage. It discusses love and loss, and human relationships and even identity far more broadly than â€œflavored romanceâ€ might imply. These unique hidden depths can be found in many of SeaBedâ€™s themes. I have never seen loss handled this way before. The story is rich like "high literature," but it's never pretentious or exclusionary. The story being â€œmatureâ€ doesn't mean it deals in depression, nor does it stray from celebrating its childish minds. The story has its sadness, but doesnâ€™t hammer tragedy into the reader. Happiness can be found in lovers doing their taxes, though there are also plenty of indulgent escapades.
SeaBed breaks a lot of conventions, in theme and in technique. Structure deserves mention again, where even chapter length is tailored to its reformatting. Finding these breaks from convention is very enjoyable, with exploration of the storytelling itself also being a thoughtful endeavor.
I do want to give particular praise to the maturity of the story. It's well grounded in reality with believable motivations and action like reading a story with real people, not fictional characters.
The cast is written very genuinely and dynamically, with depths like its themes. Creativity expresses itself in different ways. Quiet isn't equated with boring, boisterousness isn't equated with foolishness. The old and young are both treated with a lot of respect. Ideas and motivations progress intelligently. Thereâ€™s not a single flat characterâ€“even the super serious have a sense of humor. SeaBed feels very respectful to its characters in allowing nobody to fall into type. I greatly appreciated this.
The main characters are all so believably sweet, intelligent and thoughtful. Itâ€™s easy to grow attached to them. Iâ€™m particularly fond of how Sachiko is depicted as someone who is both quiet and assertive, without being mean, a great sign of her maturity. I look up to her.
There is so much love not just for the characters, but for the world: plants, animals, food, history. Characters express so much genuine interest in these things, it's hard not to share the enthusiasm. It's like exploring an encyclopedia, or a travel diary. I enjoyed looking up new encounters on my own.
The story and themes resonated with me so much that I feel like I found the endpoint of fiction. Iâ€™m very excited to experience it all again.

author: {'steamid': '76561199217264024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1360, 'last_played': 1694880092}
review: Someone in paleontology really came up with an idea "how about we make 5 stages of grief speedrun a VN, but in the most convoluted, bamboozled and roundabout way possible?" and got people on board. I didn't have the ability to differentiate what's real and what's not throughout the entirety of the story. Seabed truly is a masterclass in mindfuckery, 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982854475', 'num_games_owned': 1746, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 1488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1219, 'last_played': 1704582695}
review:
ARTWORK: well drawn and there are lots of CGs available. However, no animations are included, and the still character images along the story could use a greater variety of facial/body expressions.

STORY: the main forte of the game. The game is a linear story about 15 hours long - no story choices are offered in the game - plus side mini stories, that are skillfully written, delve pretty deep on the related subject matter, and is overall very enjoyable to read.  However, long wall of texts, often without any character stills in the background, are fairly common and in my opinion do break the pacing of the story a little. It can also be hard to distinguish who is talking in conversation scenes.

SOUND: Music is nice but the selection is fairly limited so it may become repetitive after a while. Sadly there is no voice acting.

SUMMARY: a little overpriced in relation to other games of the genre, given the price and the content available. Nevertheless, a very good read. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198186946601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1708298978}

author: {'steamid': '76561198082364431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1129, 'last_played': 1687065773}
review:
SeaBed is a strange story, but one I've quite enjoyed. I recommend going in blind since this is at its core a mystery.
I did figure out the main 'twist', aka what is up with the three main characters, very early on (around chapter 3 or so). The ending leaves quite a few things ambiguous, and will only really make sense if you've put the pieces together yourself.
It took me ~15 hours to read if I cut out time I was taking notes and theory crafting while reading.
Overall I'd give Seabed a solid 9/10 - I enjoyed it a lot, but understand you are reading this for the mystery first, everything else is secondary.

author: {'steamid': '76561198413128722', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 3380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3309, 'last_played': 1685819414}
review:
For the people who've finished the game, let me tell you something:
Narasaki is by far one of the best character ever written and I'm biased toward her for many reasons. [spoiler]There's a lots of implications about what she does and who she is, and what is the meaning of her existence, but generally speaking they are tied to the bond between Takako and Sachiko. Without her, this story wouldn't be completed; replacing her with someone else and it also couldn't be completed. The fact that the couple's bond is so heavily tied to Narasaki and that also leads to many consequences in the game, whether if it's real, or just Sachiko's imagination, it resulted in Narasaki single handedly helped Sachiko and Takako to move on but also somewhat sacrificing her memory with both of them since childhood as a consequence she expected to happen. She's an indirect cause to Sachiko's hallucination, and she's the cure to that hallucination. The ending might means otherwise; but since Sachiko already moved on, she will one day forget about the past wounds and connections tied to said wounds and live on.
Her quote shown in the description of the game: "I just like observing people" has a lots of meaning to it: As a doll, she observed the couple grows up and live together; as a psychiatrist, she observes the world around herself, and uses these observations for her research for Sachiko's condition; as a friend, she observes Sachiko and help her get stronger mentally, using her emotions and actions to analyze her thought and find a solution to her problem. It's described detailed in Narasaki's actions and thoughts showing her to be a selfless person, a human, more than a doll; through Sachiko's imagination or else. There's many more details that express Narasaki's thought of being forgotten, or her thought about the world she "lives" in... She's such a well written character that make the game even more mysterious just by her existence alone and left you with many more questions. [/spoiler]


For the people who are planning to buy this visual novel, without spoiler:
Without a doubt, this is by far one of the best written story by Visual Novel standard. 
The nature of this visual novel is "Tell and show, but not explain" with the majority leaning over "Mystery" and "Psychological" part more than "Yuri". Goes without saying, but this is not for everyone. Especially since the main topic of the visual novel focuses on a lesbian couple, but more than that it's about "pay attention to details" and without spoiler - "interpretation". Seriously, you're expected to go through the game having so much questions in your head, the ending and extras just don't help and flat out piles on the questions more and make you confused. This also gives you the effect of "boredom" since the first half of the visual novel is slice of life that, while normally wouldn't matter, it's your main clues of giving away what the hell is happening before the second half kicks off. Sounds overwhelming? I still recommend it. The visual novel gives you two way of enjoying the storytelling, which is "direct in your face" and "indirect" throughout the details in text and background in the entire story. Even if you're a braindead person like me, it's still worthwhile to invest in the latter way of enjoying the story as a lots of details cannot be ignored if you try hard enough.  So yes, buy it, the first half is so lacking I almost dropped this masterpiece, but thank lord it didn't happen.

review:
Honestly one of the best VNs I have ever read. Came for a nice yuri novel and got so much more.
If you like slowburning stories with a lot of inner monologue and subtle character writing then this is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008639857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 2304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2304, 'last_played': 1675499112}
review:
Seabad is an exceptionally fun and well written mystery/yuri visual novel about a woman suffering from a mental illness induced by a recent traumatic experience.  This story's most prominent theme is the main character's struggle with her mental instability, learning more about the circumstances surrounding it and her journey towards recovery.  However, the friendship and romance with her irreplaceable girlfriend is deeply explored and essential to the plot of this fantastic story.  In the interest of avoiding any spoilers, I'll end my preamble regarding the premise of this masterpiece.

SeaBed is a linear visual novel without any branches or choices required by the reader.  I personally prefer this format of visual novels.

I loved ALL the characters in this story.  Everyone has fun quirks, interesting personalities and intriguing lives.  Their interactions with each other are very entertaining and the dialogue is excellent.  Speaking of dialogue, my only issue with SeaBed is that after reading a large chunk of uninterrupted dialogue, you might have difficulties keeping track of who's saying what.  This doesn't happen often, it's a very minor issue and is most likely avoided altogether by experienced readers.

Again, don't worry.  There are no spoilers here.  Nada, none... All I'll say about the ending is that I enjoyed it and felt it was a fitting conclusion to this amazing story.  Certain events may confuse you at first, but there are interesting theories and reasonable explanations to them in super spoiler-heavy discussions here on steam.  However, figuring everything out on your own is a lot of fun and I only encourage you to seek answers AFTER reading SeaBed in its entirety.  

SeaBed is easily one of my favorite visual novels of all time.  This is an easy recommendation to fans of the visual novel genre or literally anyone looking for a captivating reading experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095237986', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1199, 'last_played': 1672243627}
review:
Okay, this one is a bit special.

More than just a kinetic novel you can read it almost 1:1 just like a paperback book.
Very slow but insanely confident writing.
I feel like revealing the main theme is not how it was meant to be read so I'll pass that, but I've rarely seen a piece of media talk this well about this subject especially if you're close to it.
While it's not for everyone I'm really surprised that I never heard about this before because i was NOT expecting it.

Kino?

author: {'steamid': '76561199083745769', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1107, 'last_played': 1669442448}
{'steamid': '76561198076689976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1561, 'last_played': 1669395144}
review:
What's good to know before buying it:
- it's a kinetic novel - you don't make choices
- it's a long read (I needed about 26 hours as you can see, I'm a slow reader though)
- there are no NSFW scenes. Rather, the game focuses on the emotional connection between two women which I greatly enjoyed
- you like long, slow burn stories which unfold little by little, giving you details here and there? Then this is for you
- not every question you have will be answered by the story (tag "mystery")

As of now I can safely say that SeaBed is my favorite yuri visual novel. It takes its characters, their emotions, thoughts and their relationships seriously. The game doesn't pull certain disgusting tropes yuri VNs tend to do. It's in a class of its own.
It can make you smile, it can make you sad and it really makes you think about human relationships and the human psyche in general. The story and the characters stay with me even after finishing it. It has everything what makes a story outstanding in my book.

author: {'steamid': '76561199239351366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3322, 'last_played': 1674030964}
review: Best yuri game in my mind. It is my favorite style of narrative. Great English translation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198355316398', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1040, 'last_played': 1658678761}
review:
SeaBed is one hefty visual novel. Unlike most visual novels, this one is designed to be read like a paperback book than a traditional textbox and sprite novel. However, the amount of detail used is necessary to build a complex story, which SeaBed uses to great effectiveness.

Building a complex world with complex characters and complex conditions takes time: roughly 10 chapters in fact. Detailing the main characters and their conditions - Sachiko, plagued by hallucinations of her past lover and business partner, and Takako, Sachiko's past lover suffering from developmental amnesia - encompasses a long period of in-game time, from when they first met at the age of five to when they have well established their design company. Their relationship is explored in their early childhood memories, their time at school, and their vacations around the world. On their own, they seek to understand their conditions and make sense of the world they live in, each with her own means. Taken together, SeaBed is a story of love, loss, longing, recovery, and closure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079851511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1132, 'last_played': 1698974100}
review:
This visual novel was extremely emotionally affecting for me. I'm not sure I can even reveal anything beyond the synopsis without ruining the experience since it's a straightforward kinetic novel with no choice system, and its slow burning narrative relies on an almost glacial unravelling. To not go in blind would be to do yourself a disservice. 

I will say though that any fan of the yuri sub-genre should absolutely play this, it's solid gold and I am surprised it is still relatively obscure when it should be constantly on the lips of anyone interested in the medium. The production values are pretty average since it's an indie project made by two people, but my god the journey it takes you on. I'm going to be thinking about it for a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069070934', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2088, 'last_played': 1670297562}
review:
tl;dr: If you want a VN that reads like a paperback book, brings up interesting topics and has a very intricate and rewarding to read plot, I would strongly recommend it. I would go even so far as to say that this is about as good as this genre gets and is comparable in quality even with the works of studio Key.


I don't usually leave reviews but I feel obligated to in this case, out of nothing but pure respect to the developers. I'm an avid visual novel fan and to be completely honest, I've been dissappointed in the genre for a long time. So much of it, especially in recent years, has been filled with low quality, low effort, very benign stories with little to no thought put into them. This game isn't like that though. If you're the kind of person that doesn't mind reading through text that isn't filled with action and things happening all the time, you'll be in for a captivating story with a serene atmosphere that I personally haven't quite seen anywhere else. 

It reads a lot like a traditional piece of literature, in fact there's very little in the text itself that indicates that it's a VN. No anime cliches, no over the top personalities, everything is down to earth and relatable. And yet, it still manages to paint a beautiful well tied together picture and touch on a number of interesting topics like dealing with loss, the nature of relationships and many more that I can't mention because saying anything more would already be spoiling the plot. 

When it comes to characters, none of them come off as deep or complex for most of the story, but not in a bad way. Because, as I mentioned before, the VN is very down to earth and grounded, the characters themselves feel very relatable. They all feel like puzzle pieces, which fall perfectly in their place to add to a greater sum that is the plot of the game. That's not to say they're one-dimensional, not at all. You could probably spend hours discussing every single character and their complexities, especially with the foresight you gain after finishing the game. 

I want to also give a separate thanks to Fruitbat Factory for their incredible localization. The word use is perfect, the language is colorful and descriptive and it made me feel like I wasn't losing out on meaning because of not playing the original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107108050', 'num_games_owned': 20, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1677762941}
review:
(30 hours on another account)

I've hardly read love stories so my perspectives might be a bit different.

To me SeaBed is a pretty good visual novel, it did use many convenient settings, but on the other hand, the plots have been quite interesting. It's not so much that you are solving a mystery, but rather the mystery reveals its secrets to you piece by piece.

It is true that the story has quite some chores, but if you like the subtle interactions between characters, or enjoy spotting hints of the plot/world from unapparent details, then the chores won't bore you.

I haven't read a Yuri story before so I cannot comment on that, but I do like the protagonist quite a lot - not in the love sense, but that I wish I could be her. Apparently she's a fictional character, but still.

One thing though, I don't speak Japanese, and English is not my mother tongue either, but still I feel much is lost in the translation - I could see a few places where in Japanese the description could have been more beautiful, or the words would have been more striking. Just a small pity though.

It's not perfect, but it's not far from it. I suspect SeaBed will remain one of my favourite yuri stories long after having finished it.
- There are maybe a few instances where dialogue is a bit difficult to follow and there's the odd typo, but those are the only negatives I can honestly report.
+ The art style is a bit strange, but once you get used to it, it's lovable, especially when combined with the occasional animations and the story itself I came to find.
+ Music is pretty good and made for very pleasant listening as the story progressed, with appropriate use of silence and different soundtracks for different moods, which I very much appreciated, especially in the latter stages of the story.
+ Though the majority of the story probably feels a bit more like a mystery or SoL, there is a good amount of romantic content in the story and lots of wholesome exchanges between the main couple, which I loved :)
++ The story is no doubt the main strong point for SeaBed though. Yes, it's a bit of a slow burn for how the main story all ties together and yes, the mystery elements may get confusing at times, but the journey is very much worth it for building to latter stages. I ended up quite teary for the last chapter and a half and the final tips chapter as well, so engaging was the story and the character development ;-; It took me about 45 hours to complete and I'm definitely not complaining about it, thanks to the story quality.
So in short, it's a beautifully-presented and constructed yuri VN that will definitely leave a mark if you play/ read through to completion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198864041349', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 931, 'last_played': 1678259699}
review: This game story and soundtrack is so good I've found myself just occasionally clicking the game to hear the menu soundtrack and nearly bursting into tears just from that. I LOVE this. its ending is satisfying and made me cry but then again i cry easily, for happiness and sadness, so don't take my word on that as a promise for tears. its a bit of a slow burn but the payoff is amazing, everything seems normal at first until suddenly you realize its not what it seems. The mystery really gets you thinking some outlandish things, some of which come to fruition and some of which don't. Either way its fun as hell and i wish i could wipe my memory to play it for the first time again.

review:
Sachiko and Takako are absolutely adorable together! 

But Narasaki is the hero they need (and totally deserve).

I gladly recommend SeaBed. But you need to commit because this is a bit of a slow burner, even for a visual novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198979210993', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 855, 'last_played': 1638280839}
review:
THIS REVIEW IS SPOILER FREE, feel free to read it even if you haven't played the game.
Seabed, a mystery themed visual novel with yuri elements apparently. I'm normally overly prejiduced against visual novels and mangas but I bought SeaBed because I love the publisher companY plus the artstyle and the mystery tag piqued my interest.
If you're an impatient reader, I don't suggest you SeaBed. SeaBed is a bit shy, it starts showing it's real colors to the end chapters, a late-bloomer. But the chapters before are far from unncessary. They cover a lot of background for the characters with less focus on the mystery genre and more focus on the casual, and yuri tags.

One of the main reasons why SeaBed is a great visual novel is the music and art of the novel. There are alot of photos implemented from real life with several effects to give them a more nostalgic and cozy feeling. The soundtrack is astounding, the developers really handpicked some of the most suitable and chill musics of all time. They're the perfect tracks to close your eyes and listen to while a gentle breeze sways your hair.

In conclusion, I really enjoyed SeaBed. I found it a bit boring at the start and the yuri elements seemed somewhat forced but it all led to a deep down psychoanalysis and a great mystery story. Real psychological issues, harnessed with illusory elements and creativity; Seabed's understanding and coverage of mystery is hard to come across. Great story, music and art. Starts a bit slow but blooms elegantly, I really recommend SeaBed for those who have patience to read through few chapters. 
Thank you for reading this far, you're wholesome : )

author: {'steamid': '76561198112270742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1293, 'last_played': 1691884719}
review:
Pretty good, though not quite the masterpiece it's flaunted to be.

Pros:
- The story, while at ime monotonous, has its moments. Particularly well written is Takako's character,
who starts off as a stock ditzy / genki girl and then moves into... more subtle territory.
- The occasional abstract aesthetics, especially in the title cards and interludes, add a nice artsy touch to the whole.
- The sprites and illustrations, while not exactly spectacular, are still fairly well put together. No big anatomy awkwardness / bizarre angles.

Cons:
- The story does meander, and it does so a lot. It's like a soup: chunky pieces amidst a generic sea of chatter
that is ultimately not consequential to the story.
- the background CG is messy, mixing retouched pics and 3d art in a very awkward manner.
- the sound design / music is HIDEOUS. Sound effects are canny and mixed way too loud. The music is bland, generic MIDI fare that is obtrusive and often out of sync with the scene's tone. There are outliers, but theiy are far and in between.

So, still has all the flaws of an indie production, but also all of its charms. Make of it what you will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198985413934', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1627735985}
review:
When summer comesï¼ŒI played  Highway Blossoms,I said i wlii have a happy summer hoilday.   But but but  !!!when I Play
this game I found myself still naive. (First of all, we need to know that this is a work related to mysticism.)
  Sachiko and  Takako ,how happy they were when they fell in love, how sad the story was. 
  At first I thought it was an easy novel, and slowly I felt something was wrong. I thought the story might be a tragedy, and the purpose of a tragedy that made me happy was to make me feel twice as sad at the end.


    Takako, a lively and lovely girl, met Sachiko at the age of five, then fell in love with her and moved in with her. She suffered from some kind of mental illness in her childhood, which worsened, causing her to lose her memory and forget many pieces of memory, and eventually died of the disease.
    Sachiko, who is fond of reading, is not interested in most of the things around her,she is very gentle. She and Takako are lovers.
    There are many other unforgettable characters (except Inukai  haha!)

    [spoiler] 
    Here are some of my speculations: after Takako died, Sachiko couldn't accept the fact that he just thought Takako was gone. On the other hand, after Takako died, she came to the heart of Sachiko, the world Sachiko unconsciously created for her, and will live here forever. Both people in both worlds have forgotten part of their common memories. When the last two men dialed the phone and heard each other's voices, they chatted for a long time until they ran out of coins. 
and then the final bond between the two people is gone. 

    In the end, Sachiko's vision and tinnitus were completely cured by Narasaki and part of her life about Takako was erased. 
Maybe she has forgotten the fact that Takako passed away, only kept the memories of the past that she shared, and stepped into a new life. 
    On the other side of Takako, she and three other people in the nursing home are also traveling in the world created by Sachiko. At the end of the story, Takako sees Sachiko on a trip, but disappears the next second. She firmly believes that Sachiko will come to her and will be by her side. Because Sachiko created all this for her.[/spoiler]
   
  " Sachiko would eventually come  here 
   And when she did, I had to be ready
   After all,She did this all for me"
      [u] What a pity that there is no Chinese translation for this game. What a pity! What a pity![/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198331411585', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2743, 'last_played': 1625346280}
review:
For [url=https://vndb.org/v19273/reviews#review] those of you [/url] that already wrote a review for SeaBed, I almost don't feel like I'm capable enough of doing it justice as you did. Such unorthodox work is worth experiencing by everyone in their own way, at their own pace.

A friend of mine called it a passion project, and a passion project it is. A very subtle, hypnotic piece, its tempo, Adagio. It took me a long time to finish it because I was almost forced to take a step back, breathe in, slowly exhale, and read it at its own pace. I could not fight it, nor rush through it, since the pace is an absolute constant.

There is nothing quite like this is the vn medium, and candidly, also in literature. Its narration to dialogue ratio is rather high, making everything any characters say have importance and meaning. SeaBed is full of these long existential dialogues, and I would argue that they are the best part of the story in some ways. 

It is, by all means, a sound novel and it makes use of that concept very well, and it results in the story being very atmospheric at all times. That, combined with the photographic backgrounds and the gorgeous bgm makes it for a memorable time. That OST is filled to the brim with songs I can't possibly do justice with words alone; every single one out of those 63(!!) songs is perfect in its own way and works perfectly for each scene it accompanies. 

The main part of a visual novel though, and for all literature too, the writing: This reads nothing like anything I've read so far, especially among vns. I must give credit for the fantastic translation; most vns are translated well, but SeaBed highlights it with its way of narration and storytelling - every minute detail is described beautifully, painting a most vivid image in the readers' mind.

The characters are just like everything else about SeaBed, grounded. Now that I think of it, there is not a single scene when they are not calm, or deliberately taking their time with everything, which is technically SeaBed's signature style, and it wouldn't work any other way.

A mystery novel told like no other, even major twists are told in such a way that the reader is able to put everything together by the time it arrives. And that non-linear storytelling is what it is all about - putting small fragments and pieces together to form a clear narrative. 

SeaBed is at its best when it's just vague enough that the player needs to stop and think about everything they read thus far in order to make sense of what is happening, and those moments happen a lot. I kept a small notebook where I jotted thoughts of mine when I felt like I needed to and looking back on them, some I got right, and some I got oh so horribly wrong, and that's the beauty of SeaBed.

I can't recommend this enough for people looking for something like this. It might not be for everyone, and it's a slow-burner, but that's how it supposed to be, so please enjoy it the way it is intended to.

Note: Actual playtime was around 25-30 hours. These are my spoiler-free opinions.
Seabed is an extremely unique work. It is the only work that has actively made me sleepy while reading it but would still be worthy of being deemed kino. There are a million small touches that make it extremely good. I have a lot to say, but I don't really want to put it here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059779956', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1086, 'last_played': 1620615069}
review:
[h1]Yuri? Mystery?[/h1]
SeaBed is, as it says on the store page, a yuri-themed mystery visual novel. It is not, however, [i]about[/i] yuri, or in other words, how society views lesbian relationships, or how characters come to terms with being gay, or anything like that.
The yuri is basically taken for granted. The focus of the story is directed mostly at the mystery aspect, and the slice of life scenes, which make up the majority of the game. That is not to say the slice of life scenes are filler, or don't tie into the mystery in any way. Quite the opposite...

[h1]Unconventional storytelling[/h1]
SeaBed is not a novel that will choreograph every important piece of information so you know when to pay attention and when not to. It doesn't insult the reader's intelligence like that; instead, you're expected to pay attention to every passage. Sometimes it will not be immediately obvious why what you're reading is supposed to be relevant to the story, and this may be due to the fact that there isn't just one thematic throughline in SeaBed. 
Many different ideas are presented, but not necessarily explored in depth. It's a novel both for those who like to let their mind wander, and those who like to dive into a particular concept to try to understand it. Picking out a specific word or sentence and running with it to see where it takes you can become a sort of symbolic dialogue between the author and the reader. This, to me, is the appeal of the mystery genre: the ability for the spectator to shape the fictional world in their mind.

[h1]Ruminations on the mystery genre[/h1]
I've seen so many murder mysteries, whodunits and police procedurals, and the worst part for me is always the ending, the moment when the culprit is revealed. Every time I consume a mystery novel or show, my main worry is that the author will give too much away, limiting my sense of imagination and destroying any possibility for re-reading/re-watching. [strike]My favorite movies include CachÃ© and Memories of Murder.[/strike]
Because what good is a mystery if it ends as soon as you see the ending? Once it ends, it's no longer a mystery, and then there's nothing left to think about anymore.
SeaBed, being more of a missing person mystery, absolutely sticks the landing, and it's not because it doesn't give anything away - in fact it is quite simple to sum up the story in a couple of sentences once you've finished it - but rather because there isn't just one element of mystery to SeaBed, or even just mystery. The devil is in the details, and this novel contains so many thematic throughlines tying everything together, so many different ideas, feelings, and images, each one expressed so sincerely but so deliberately that you'll re-read sentences four times over, not wanting to miss a single word. It's not just a fictional puzzle to be pieced together, but a reflection of the real world with real things to teach, and an endearing manifestation of the author's worldview which captures the true essence of the mystery genre. 
You won't get all the answers right away, because most answers are not definitive. The only right answers are the ones that feel right to you. Once you have finished this visual novel, you'll still have plenty more mysteries to solve. The fun never ends!

[h1]Translation and conclusion[/h1]
While writing this review I found out that the translator for this game, Conjueror, [url=https://twitter.com/DistantValhalla/status/1160226411677986817]passed away in 2019 at the age of 29[/url]. This hit me like a brick, since I love the translation for this game so much that it inspired me to try to become a translator myself. I'm not a very good writer, though, so this ended up being mostly a stream of consciousness piece.
I know a lot of this review won't make much sense until you've actually read the VN, but I'm hoping just by seeing how passionate I am about it will get you to consider buying it.
I hope I was able to replicate here, the feelings that SeaBed gave me, if even just a little bit. It definitely deserves more attention for all the effort that went into it.

Estimated reading time is 19 hours. Contains no voice acting and no branching paths/choices.

author: {'steamid': '76561198446893870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1619231039}
review: Immersive, but not exciting.  Since this story is described as a "mystery," I expected more answers at the end.  It was definitely psychological, and I do like psychological stories, but ones with more action and plot.  Most of the game is reading about the the protagonists' traveling experiences, and descriptions of day-to-day life.  It can be soothing and relaxing to experience after a long day, even therapeutic, but at the end my major feeling was relief that it was over and I could move on to other games/stories.  I did like the beautiful, realistic, and well-developed relationship between the women in love.  It's not a bad story at all.  It's like a meditation on the ways people you love will impact you forever, even when they're gone.  But in the end I can't see myself recommending this to anyone I know.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201613371', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 1148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1148, 'last_played': 1619045172}
review:
[u]Warning: This VN is very slow-paced.[/u]
SeaBed is an immersive yuri themed mystery kinetic novel that can easily take around 19+ hours to complete. With 93 unique CGâ€™s, developed characters and multiple soundtracks, itâ€™s easy to get absorbed in the story. 
In SeaBed, you play and switch between three different perspectives.
Sachiko the designer, Takako the adventurer, and Narasaki the psychiatrist.

All three girls were childhood friends; however, overtime, Sachiko and Takako naturally fell into the role of lovers. Both quitting their jobs and becoming co-owners of Clover Design Office while taking regular vacations to new places overseas, life is going very well, until it isnâ€™t. 
Takako is discovered to have developmental amnesia, and one day, mysteriously vanishes. 
Find her.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262452338', 'num_games_owned': 1861, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 1940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1940, 'last_played': 1614262611}
review:
[h3]Spoiler Free[/h3]
FIrst of all, I want to say I feel very fortunate to have discovered this visual novel in the sea of lowbrow anime smut.

[b]SeaBed[/b] is a very unorthodox work for the VN medium. It reads like an actual paperback novel with very descriptive and vivid prose, there are no anime tropes or clichÃ©s (despite the game using anime style art), its characters are extremely realistic and their actions and thoughts are easy to relate to.

At its core, it's a very powerful story of love between two women, their happiness, struggle and loss. The prose is slow and almost hypnotical, savoring every moment of the seemingly mundane everyday events, and making you slow down and think about it. It's definitely not something that you pick up for a cheap thrill, you need to be in the right mood and frame of mind to truly appreciate this work, especially given the heavy subject matter in its later parts. The novel rewards a patient reader with carefully crafted mystery elements and subtle foreshadowing.

I was so enthralled with it I blew 28 hours on it in just 4 days. I just couldn't stop reading. The prose felt very similar to early modern Japanese literature, e.g. Natsume Soseki and Yasunari Kawabata's works, with its great attention to minute detail, human psyche and beauty of nature. It might seem dry but it paints very vivid images in your mind's eye.

The protagonists are around 30 years old, and you do need some baggage in your life to empathize with the characters, so I'd recommend this for an older audience. I'm 34 myself and felt like this was written exactly for my age group.

Audio/visuals wise, the novel features 100 beautiful CG's and a touching (mostly piano) soundtrack with tracks like [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z8uHsbuQb4k]this[/url] and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ge2MEw6mimc]this[/url]. There's no voice acting of any kind, but it makes clever use of environmental sounds to enhance the atmosphere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198808972894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1399, 'last_played': 1649287311}
review:
I like to think that there comes a point in time in one's life where they encounter a piece of work that leaves them completely mesmerized and stupefied upon completion. For me, SeaBed was that piece of work.

SeaBed's narrative is nothing short of enthralling, with a cast of captivating characters that will have you fully invested in their everyday lives and musings. The music, visuals, and characters all coalesce to create a lively, immersive world that is simultaneously grounded and ethereal. The main trio of Sachiko, Takako, and Narasaki all tell the story through gripping perspectives that play off of each other beautifully, forming an enigmatic mystery that will leave you guessing page after page. 

Although it is yuri-themed, SeaBed focuses more on depicting each of the main characters as flawed human beings with dreams and struggles of their own, making it very easy for you to empathize with them and visualize them as real people. There is no overt plot to guide the narrative; the internal conflicts and desires of each of the characters carry the story forward as they try to make sense of their own respective places in the world. Regardless, the intimacy between Sachiko and Takako is heartfelt and is most definitely the core of this wonderful visual novel.

I cannot recommend SeaBed enough â€” it is an unorthodox work that defies normal conventions of storytelling, and the experience of reading through it for the first time with no prior knowledge of the story is a once in a lifetime experience. I promise that it will be very difficult for SeaBed to leave your heart once you complete it.

review: An atmospheric and understated psychological-mystery about grief. Very slow but also very detailed, the kind of story that tempts you to immediately reread it after you finish. author: {'steamid': '76561198006758487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1606433277}
review:
The badly mixed sound effects that are either too loud or too bass heavy are only surpassed by the irritatingly jerking text used to simulate movement.
The story was intriguing and the narration unique but not in a bad way.
I really wanted to like the game but the mentioned negatives killed it for me in the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198295410422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1699530479}
review:
I don't usually play visual novels, but some friends recommended this to me and so far I've been really enjoying it. The art, the music and the characters are all *really* good. I know this may be a turn-off to some people but it plays out like an actual novel with no input from the "player" and that is something I appreciate because the anxiety that comes with making a decision in a story like that is a bit much for me lol. Unlike other types of games with visual novels if you regret a choice or want to see a different ending you don't get to do anything aside from press skip over and over until you get to that segment again and then pick a different option which is really tedious. At least with RPGs you can change things up so making your way back to that point is fun. 

My tangent aside, this is a really good visual novel and I'd recommend it strongly, especially to those like me who usually aren't into VNs for the reasons I gave.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960586723', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1575, 'last_played': 1598764289}
review:
An interesting and emotive exploration of non-standard self-coping mechanisms for those dealing with traumatic loss.  Nice to see a game in the yuri genre where homosexuality is neither remarkable, nor problematic in it's presentation. It's just there.

The game ultimately could've been more concise in its execution, but is heart-felt and touching all the same. Take your time, don't rush, ponder muchly.

Can definitely recommend.

(For those who can't read Japanese, I can attest to the general quality of the localization, although I strongly  recommend you avoid looking things up in a Japanese dictionary until after you've finished.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198067591926', 'num_games_owned': 635, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1677805235}
review:
One of my all time favourite Visual Novels. I pirated it on my first playthrough but loved it enough to buy it here on steam at full price. 

Its a very slow story but the writing is superb. Its not a story that is following a formula or preset path, this is a story about psychology, memory, the unconscious, adulthood. It takes place when the characters are well into their 20s and struggling to deal with the realities of adult life. 

I love the music. 

The artwork isn't brilliant but it does what it needs to do well, the character portraits and CGs aren't ugly but you've probably seen better. 

Would recommend more people should try this game, it's a true hidden gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997014523', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1593793747}
review:
There's very little plot early on, it's always "I did this, I did that". All of the writing is like this, there isn't even any humor. It's just an account of extremely mundane events, I can't imagine who would enjoy reading this.

Additionally, you can't skip unread text except by holding Enter, there's a delay when you do that, making skimming difficult. The game has many long, generic animations such as characters moving across the screen that you can't skip unless you were holding Enter beforehand.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004885007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1583810869}
review:
I'm giving up on SeaBed after finishing Chapter 3. That's around 15 hours at my likely slow reading speed.

I don't recall minding Tolkien's meandering descriptive passages and exposition on supporting characters when first reading The Lord of the Rings, and yet I cannot fathom what purpose over half of SeaBed's passages serve, if not incessantly prolonging the actual development of the narrative in order to create some illusory impression of deep, meaningful writing. While a small handful of details give the reader subtle clues that something is amiss, the majority of visual description is either contradicted or made redundant by the accompanying on-screen images. Why, then, is this a *visual* novel to begin with? Somehow it reminds me of how many JRPGS revel in repetitive look-alike battling for seemingly no other reason than to appease some arbitrary genre expectation of how many hours such games should last.

Likewise, while some of the dialogue provides insight into characters' personalities and philosophies, I found the majority of it to be redundant and mundane. I've lost count of the number of times two characters engaged in some drawn-out, inane conversation seemingly only to conceal one or two individual details (at most!) that hint at a larger mystery. I wouldn't consider myself to be someone who can't handle a slow-paced, character-focused story- for instance, I would probably consider Marimite one of my favorite anime series- but SeaBed needlessly delays relevant progression of its core idea too often, for too long, and for too little gain.

While it's theoretically possible that reading the rest of the story would put everything into proper context and make me reverse a lot of my opinions, realistically I'd say that's highly unlikely. For me personally, this is simply poor writing. Or, phrased more diplomatically, it's a style of writing that simply does not hold enough appeal for me.
developer_response:
Thanks for the checking out SeaBed and sticking with it that far.

Sorry to hear the narrative wasn't to your liking. The chapters get shorter toward the end so you are actually quite far already.

"Everything happens for a reason" is also true for practically any passage in this story. That said, one of the fans made the observation that you're significantly more likely to enjoy SeaBed if you're a fan of at least 2 of these genres:

-Yuri
-Slice of life
-Mystery

That's why it's completely understandable that it's not to everyone's liking, and we try to emphasize these elements in promoting it. 

We heartily recommend anyone to check out the free demo which gives a very representative idea of the style of the game and whether you'll like it or not.

review:
[h1]Not many Visual Novels on the English market nowadays have superb writing as with what SeaBed offers.[/h1] 

Maybe that is perhaps because that SeaBed is less of a visual novel and more like a fantastic piece of literature (with music and pictures... but, like, not like a visual novel). Why is this so? There is definitely more behind the narrative than other visual novels (and especially with the limited selection of yuri visual novels offered on Steam). Although I would like to explain further on why SeaBed's plot is so much different compared to other visual novels, there is little that can be said without spoiling the richness of the story that is to be uncovered.

What I can say is, however, is that you should expect to be completely confused during the story and [b]after[/b] finishing the story. The story is also linear, meaning of course only one ending and with that one ending is where all of the writing is dedicated to.

To be stressed once again, this visual novel reads more akin to a book than that of a traditional visual novel most people are familiar with. [b]There will not be a lot of anime-like antics[/b]. There will be excessive details on little things that would bore the normal anime-watcher/VN player. If you do not prefer reading traditional, paper-bound novels often, then chances are you may not get very far into the text without sheer determination to make the most of your money spent on this title. [b]After all, reading this novel is the estimated equivalence of reading a 700 page novel (like Harry Potter!).[/b] [u]Expect a gameplay length of roughly twenty hours.[/u]

[i]As a reference, the Achievements Page shows that out of all the buyers of this game (including bundles), only roughly 25% of players got past the Prologue.[/i] [b]The Prologue. Only 25% finished it.[/b]

[h1]If you can handle the hard labor of getting through a lengthy book simply for a grand ol' time, look no further than to SeaBed. It will not disappoint the dedicated.[/h1]

[i]P.S: It has yuri. Good yuri.[/i] [spoiler]The lovers are also actual adults, mind you.[/spoiler]

review:
SeaBed gets the reader invested into a relationship and presents a mystery a little by little to hook the reader in for the long run.

It takes some time and patience to get into this story but after that, it makes sure to occupy the reader's mind even for weeks after they finish.

Without spoiling too much, SeaBed will hurt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088849409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1278, 'last_played': 1559720691}
review: A rare story of cherishing memories and coping with loss through the lens of a genuine lover of life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026157773', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1287, 'last_played': 1559035458}
review:
one of the most beautiful, thought-engaging visual novels i have ever read

as a forewarning, the story can be slow to some. for me, the world seabed has created for itself is so breathtaking, so magical, that the slow pace of it all never bothered me.

absolutely lovely novel centered around the relationship between two women, give it a chance if you're interested in girls love or mysteries

author: {'steamid': '76561197970296271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2680, 'last_played': 1557132718}
review:
There is not much point describing the details, given this is a mystery novel, so I'll just recommend this to people who like contemplative and slow moving novels. It is a full length novel, first and foremost, rather that your typical "choose your route" affair you see these days.

I'd say if you enjoyed VN:s like "The House in Fata Morgana", this might be up your alley as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999125917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1660, 'last_played': 1556714629}
review:
[h1]SeaBed is an underappreciated gem in this [i]now[/i] flooded market of visual novels. [/h1]

I didn't know what to expect when I started reading. And honestly, it was hard to get into at first. The prologue would simply not hook me. But once the plot points started dropping, I was fully dedicated to the story. This is not something you rush, however. Take your time reading the story. It's a slow burn, not something you speed through and binge in a day. 

The time I spent reading this was one hell of an experience. The more you read, the more it leaves you confused and the more you understand, the more you want to know. The kind of, "I really want to spoil myself, but I don't want to be spoilered!" feeling. And take that by heart. No spoilers. The mystery is what makes this so good. And by the time I neared the end, I could not stop crying. This is someone who rarely cries at fiction.

If you want a good story that will leave an impression on you and a hole in your heart, this is for you. If you're someone who needs everything spoonfed to you, I can't say you'll enjoy it as much, but I would still recommend you give it a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198304974200', 'num_games_owned': 1857, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 2779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2575, 'last_played': 1551570143}
review:
[h1]Um estudo psicolÃ³gico sobre amor[/h1]
Sea Bed Ã© um jogo maravilhoso! Ã‰ difÃ­cil fazer uma anÃ¡lise sem dar spoilers do jogo, entÃ£o tentarei ser breve.
A escrita do jogo foge muito do padrÃ£o de visual novels, nÃ£o hÃ¡ "cenas anime fofas", a escrita Ã© como a de um livro normal (o que nÃ£o Ã© algo ruim), os backgrounds na maioria sÃ£o fotografias, a arte Ã© muito bonita e simples. A histÃ³ria se desenvolve de forma lenta, mas tenha paciÃªncia pois hÃ¡ alguns mistÃ©rios e uma drama fortemente sentimental que culminam num final maravilhoso. A histÃ³ria Ã© voltada a tema psicolÃ³gico, mas nÃ£o tenha medo que nÃ£o Ã© nada cheio de termos complexos, apenas vÃ¡rias trocas de perspectivas e linhas de tempo. Resumindo, Ã© um bom jogo mais voltado para fÃ£s de visual novels que tambÃ©m gostam de livros e temas psicolÃ³gicos com romance.

[h1] A psychological study of love [/h1]
Sea Bed is a wonderful game! It's hard to do an analysis without spoilers of the game, so I'll try to be brief.
The writing of the game runs away from the standard of visual novels, there are no "cute anime scenes", writing is like a normal book (which is not a bad thing), backgrounds are mostly photographs, art is very beautiful and simple. The story unfolds slowly, but be patient as there are some mysteries and a strongly sentimental drama that culminate in a wonderful ending. The story is psychologically focused, but do not be afraid that it's not full of complex terms, just multiple exchanges of perspectives and timelines. In short, it's a good game more for fans of visual novels who also love books and psychological themes with romance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345719169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1547991994}
review:
I just simply could not get immersed in the story as I have with other visual novels I've played. I'm sure it does get better later on, but after 30 minutes of playing, I realised this was not a style of storytelling I was personally a fan of and wasn't worth the money I had spent.

This visual novel is for people who enjoy reading a lot of books. This has detailed and lengthy dialogue which can be hard to keep focus if you are not accustomed to it, so if you're new to visual novels/don't read much, you may get overwhelmed and burnt out after about half an hour.

I'd personally say to give this a go. You may like it if you are accustomed to reading detailed books with a story you have to really think about.

If you are just looking for something you can read and enjoy without too much thought, I'd say to look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168485644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1586899623}
review:
Up there with Fun Home as one of the greatest works of LGBT art this century, of not ever.  Staunchly anti-fantasy based entirely on social psychology, memory, and relationship building.  One of the few games that has ever made me cry, a true standout for storytelling in videogames.   
  Unfortuanately I really can't elaborate further without spoiling, this is a game that you need to go into blind.  One of the most professional doujin works in any genre I have ever seen. 
 Recommended to: slice of life mange/anime fans, people starved for either nuanced realistic depictions of psychology and/or LGBT representation in games, psychological drama fans

author: {'steamid': '76561198010090636', 'num_games_owned': 592, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1280, 'last_played': 1561477040}
review: Seabed grants you pleasure from piecing the bits together, as well as noticing clever red herrings and foreshadowing. It has a decent amount of artwork for the medium-length doujin work. A lot of people find it pacing slow, but it's not that bad in my opinion, the last 4 chapters are extremely engaging and you read them eagerly in one breath. The game, however, has some descriptions which are a bit too thorough for my personal taste. The 'yuri' part of the story is almost non-existant, as the game explores the themes of memory and human psyche, rather than the theme of homosexuality. If you are experienced in the visual novel field or you feel like the game resonates with you on an entirely different level, go for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993362300', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1254, 'last_played': 1647299728}
review:
SeaBed is a story about dealing with loss, and coming out stronger on the other side. The main character, Sachiko, suffers from hallucinations of her former girlfriend, and seeks treatment to return to a more normal life. We follow her journey as she dives deep into her own psyche and ultimately comes to accept her past and move forward. The game is a kinetic novel where the player makes no choices, but simply follows along with the text. The story is engrossing enough that I would often lay in bed at night after playing, running though what Iâ€™ve learned in my head, trying to fit the clues into the broader narrative. The writing is superb, and of such quality that small discontinuities between scenes are important clues and not a product of poor writing (for example: there is a table with two chairs. One character sits in one chair and falls asleep. A second character enters the room and sits in the other chair. A third character enters the room and sits an empty chair, despite there only being two chairs in the room. This is an important clue about the true nature of one of the characters). Itâ€™s nice to play a game that rewards the reader for paying attention to the little things, as they herald bigger discoveries. My hunches were usually on the mark, yet the game is never heavy-handed with pointing out major revelations. Instead, they flow naturally, and fit like puzzle pieces into the broader narrative. It made me cry at several spots, but Iâ€™m easily affected by death, so your mileage may vary. The story is far from being always depressing though, and many scenes show the characters going on fun adventures. While these scenes donâ€™t really propel the story forward, they do allow us to grow closer to the characters and care for them more deeply. The story wraps up very well at the end, tying up all the loose ends seamlessly. Itâ€™s so engrossing that I would actually feel a chill when a character would describe how cold she was feeling, even though I played this game in the middle of summer.

The CGs are colorful and well drawn, and the characters are well proportioned, but they have the slightly rough look of a doujin game. This doesnâ€™t hurt the appeal of the characters, and, if anything, adds to the overall charm of the game. Most backgrounds are filtered photographs like in Tsukihime, but others are 3D CG models of high quality. I felt there was a bit of a discontinuity when the game would switch between the photographs and the 3D CG background between scenes, but it never breaks the immersion, and the text is always in agreement with the background (like if a character walks over to a bookshelf with a glass cabinet, there really is a bookshelf with a glass cabinet in the background. I really appreciate that level of attention to detail). The 3D CG backgrounds are so good, that I canâ€™t help but wonder if the photograph backgrounds were placeholders that were just never replaced for whatever reason. At any rate, the art is pleasing and great to look at. 

The text is placed over the background instead of in a box at the bottom of the screen. This means that the speakerâ€™s name isnâ€™t displayed during dialogue, but the characters have such distinct ways of speaking that I almost always knew who was speaking, which is a tribute to the quality of the writing and translation. And on the few times that I wasnâ€™t sure who was speaking, the characters would change their expressions often enough that it made it clear who was speaking again, so I never felt lost for long. There are a few typos, but they are minor and donâ€™t effect the story.

The music is catchy and always fits the overall feel of the scene well. Upbeat tracks are used for happy scenes, and slower, more somber songs are used for mysterious or sad portions of the story. The use of certain tracks would kind of foreshadow how a scene was going to play out, but I guess thatâ€™s unavoidable with a story of this length (it took me 20 hours using the auto-read function). Sound effects are peppered throughout the story to enhance the text, and they fit so well I could almost smell an egg being fried when the sound effect of sizzling food was played.

Overall, I felt that SeaBed was an incredible journey, with a deeply engaging story and unforgettable characters. While I guess it wouldnâ€™t be unfair to call it a nakige (crying game), it earns its tears through the quality of the writing and my attachment to the characters. Itâ€™s definitely worth the purchase for anyone interested in yuri or mystery games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046193538', 'num_games_owned': 701, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 1194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1194, 'last_played': 1534707193}
review:
I went into SeaBed expecting nothing more than a Mystery VN with Yuri elements in it. And if you boiled down the tremendous amount of detail, narrative and developments down to its very core, those two things can describe this VN, although not doing the VN any of the justice it deserves; that's like calling a five-star restaurant's three-course meal simply "food."

SeaBed is a somewhat lengthy Kinetic Novel (i.e. there are no choices for the player to make that affect the path of the story) which I'd estimate is around 20 hours long. And I will say, the story is a very slow-burn; if you're not someone who's willing to appreciate all the details and follow a story through to the very end, SeaBed is not for you. If you're the kind of person who just glances and skips over dialogue thinking it won't be important, this story is definitely not for you. At first, it may appear as a mere Yuri Slice-Of-Life simulator where everything that's happening is filler, but even those moments are important; the end of the (rather lengthy) prologue slams you with an introductory plot twist that makes you question the events of the entire story, including the prologue you just read. Because of this, the story can be a bit hard-to-follow sometimes, but it's structured that way on purpose and it isn't meant to simply confuse the reader.

SeaBed is quite an experience that kept me thinking, questioning and feeling things with each chapter. I had many questions, and each time a question seemed to get answered, I'd have even more questions. However, after the end credits [spoiler]and reading the extra scenes unlocked after the end, after reading the very last 3 lines of the entire story, everything clicked into place.[/spoiler] I absolutely recommend SeaBed, even at full price. This type of story is very difficult to recommend without spoiling anything, but it's definitely worth it if you enjoy a narrative that provides immersive detail and being very subtle about "there's something strange happening" but just enough to keep you wanting more.
